head.title: A Tale of 2 Babies, And More Questions

hedline.hl1: A Tale of 2 Babies, And More Questions

abstract.p: Letter from Janet Levoff (New York Academy of Medicine) says birth of conjoined twins raises essential themes of medical ethics: who shall live and who shall die, and who decides (Aug 10 article)

block.p: Re ''2 Babies, 1 Heart, 90 Minutes for a Miracle'' (front page, Aug. 10):
The birth of conjoined twins raises essential themes of medical ethics: Who shall live and who shall die? Who decides? How?
Re ''2 Babies, 1 Heart, 90 Minutes for a Miracle'' (front page, Aug. 10):
The birth of conjoined twins raises essential themes of medical ethics: Who shall live and who shall die? Who decides? How?
The situation points to decision-making processes that are anything but clear, neither for medical professionals nor families.

In the case of the Sotos, the family featured in your article, would they have considered giving birth to conjoined twins with any hope of a limited life span rather than sacrifice one child for the sake of the other?
There are instances of conjoined twins who live satisfying, though unusual, lives.
They are not like other twin sets, should not be regarded as such, and thus challenge society at a very basic level: Are we capable of respecting the dignity of the other?
If the Sotos could have experienced the successful birth of conjoined twins, would their doctors have readily taken part? Would we have welcomed their birth?
JANET LEVOFF Director of Communications New York Academy of Medicine New York, Aug. 10, 2000
